runs.text: Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this story is about a duck named Lucky that likes to fly high in the sky. Have students find the flying duck in the picture. Ask them to predict what Lucky might see high in the sky.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
is something that is hard to do.
Example: Climbing the worlds tallest mountain is a
Ask: What is something that would be a
for you to do? Tell your partner about it.
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names how the airplane pilots look at Lucky. (stare)
How can you tell flying higher and higher is a
for Lucky? Find the sentences that answer the question.
What makes it difficult for Lucky to fly as high as the jets? How does he react to failing to overcome this
? Who or what helped you deal with it?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisper-read each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss the related words that form phrases in sentences 2 and 4.
Model how to chunk the text into meaningful phrases as you read each sentence.
Have students echoread the sentences, replicating your phrasing.

Read the title. Explain that this is a comic strip. Point out that the text inside the speech bubbles shows what each character says. Explain that when you dare someone, you challenge them to do something.
For the first reading, have students echoread the text with you. Then pair students to reread the comic. Each partner reads the speech bubbles for the boy or girl.
Prompt students to find all the words with
spellings in the comic and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Write the sentences on the board and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that students will read about the game of bowling. Explain that the words
are special terms used in bowling.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
is a group of words that have special meanings when used within certain topics.
includes words such as bat, mitt, base, home run, and dugout.
might you use to talk about soccer? What
might you use to talk about a sport, game, or hobby that you like?
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names the bowling jargon for knocking down all the pins in your second roll. (spare)
What instructions in the text help you know how points are scored in bowling? Find sentences that answer these questions.
Why do bowlers want to roll as many strikes as they can?
change when they are used in bowling jargon?
Then ask them to chorally read it.
spellings. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have them read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss the different end punctuation for sentences 1 (question mark), 2 (period), and 3 (exclamation point).
Model how you change your intonation when reading a question (raise voice at end) or exclamation (read with excitement). Have students echo read the sentences, replicating your intonation.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.

Explain that this text describes the things found inside a bowling alley. It includes a diagram with labels. Authors include diagrams to help readers understand the parts of something important to remember. The labels help readers identify the key parts.
Guide students through a reading of the selection, including the diagram.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the diagram.

Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the e-book for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read a folktale about a cowboy hero.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means to be described as morebigger/better/worsethan the truth.
when he said the rainy day was the worst day of his life.
Ask: How would you describe your favorite food in an
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the phrase that tells where Bill rode the tornado. (into the air)
How did Bill create Death Valley? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How can you tell that the story of Pecos Bill is exaggerated? Why do you think the author wrote the story in this way?
Who is a fictional or real-life hero you know about? What makes this person a hero?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this is a fictional, or made-up, story about people who live on another planet. Ask students how living on another planet might be different than living on Earth.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means going against something or being the opposite.
feelingsboth excitement and nervousnessabout moving to a new city.
Ask: When was a time when you felt
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names what can get tangled in a spacesuit helmet. (hair)
What makes living on another planet challenging? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How can you tell the narrator has conflicting feelings about the discovery of the scratches on the dome? Why do you think the narrator has these feelings?
Would you be interested in living on another planet? Why or why not?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
